title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Group includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson and senior representatives selected by the Undersecretary. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury is chaired by the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes. It includes senior representatives from various offices and bureaus within the Department of the Treasury to conduct contingency planning. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury, chaired by the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes, conducts contingency planning for the rapid imposition of economic sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury considers factors such as the vulnerability of the foreign country to sanctions, the effectiveness of different types of sanctions, the cost to the US economy, and whether unilateral or multilateral sanctions would be more effective. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury will review and identify specific and general problems with each economic sanctions program administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury will identify specific problems with each economic sanctions program and general issues with United States economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes will coordinate the development of US economic sanctions policy with various government agencies. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury meets at least once a month to ensure equal sharing of information related to US economic sanctions policy among relevant government agencies. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes or the Secretary of the Treasury can assign personnel to assist the Group in carrying out its functions. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes or the Secretary of the Treasury can assign Treasury personnel to assist the Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The Group may consult with experts from academia, research organizations, and the private sector. The Group must submit annual reports to Congress. The Committees on Foreign Affairs and Ways and Means of the House of Representatives, along with other relevant committees, are required to submit a report to Congress detailing contingency planning, identified problems, strategy creation, interagency coordination, and policy experts. The report to Congress must include an overview of interagency coordination, a list of consulted policy experts, and a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment. It may also contain a classified index and closed briefings for specific committees. The comprehensive sanctions impact assessment required for economic sanctions programs must use various research methods and evaluate the impact on both foreign and US economies. The sanctions impact assessment for economic sanctions programs must include an evaluation of the impact on the economy of the foreign country or entity, the US economy, and any behavioral changes in response to the sanctions. The report will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website, excluding classified information. The subsection, excluding classified information, will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website and can be updated as sanctions programs are lifted or modified. Definitions for "executive agency" and "United States economic sanctions policy" are provided in this section. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group will report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury as per the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group will report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.
